analyzed: milindapañha

original: Meṇḍakapañha🔽Sabbaññutañāṇavagga
analyzed: meṇḍakapañha  sabbaññuta ñāṇa vagga
translated: The Questions of Menander🔽The Chapter about Omniscience

original: 9. Arahantaabhāyanapañha
analyzed: arahanta abhāyanapañha
translated: The Questions of the Wanderer Abhaya

original: “Bhante nāgasena, bhāsitampetaṁ bhagavatā—
analyzed: bhante nāgasena bhāsitam petam bhagavatā
translated: “Though, revered sir, this was said by the Blessed One:

original: ‘vigatabhayasantāsā arahanto’ti.
analyzed: vigata bhaya santāsāḥ
translated: ‘Arahats are free from fear and trembling,’

original: Puna ca nagare rājagahe dhanapālakaṁ hatthiṁ bhagavati opatantaṁ disvā pañca khīṇāsavasatāni pariccajitvā jinavaraṁ pakkantāni disāvidisaṁ ekaṁ ṭhapetvā theraṁ ānandaṁ.
analyzed: puna ca nagare rājagahe dhanapālakam hatthim bhagavati opatantam disvā pañca khīṇāsava satāni pariccajitvā jina varam pakkantāni disāvidisam ekam ṭhapetvā theram ānanda
translated: and again, in the city of Rājagaha, five hundred arahats, having seen the elephant Dhanapāla rush at the Blessed One, abandoned their attainment and went away in all directions, leaving one arahat, the elder Ānanda, behind.

original: Kiṁ nu kho, bhante nāgasena, te arahanto bhayā pakkantā, paññāyissati sakena kammenāti🔽dasabalaṁ pātetukāmā pakkantā, udāhu tathāgatassa atulaṁ vipulamasamaṁ pāṭihāriyaṁ
analyzed: kim nu kho bhante nāgasena te arahantaḥ bhayā pakkantā paññāyissati sakena kammena ati  dasa balam pātetu kāmā pakkantā udāhu tathāgatassa atulam vipulam asamam pāṭihāriya
translated: Now, revered Nāgasena, did those arahats go away because they were afraid, or did they go away because they were thinking: ‘Let it be known that the Blessed One is great by his own deeds’?🔽Did they go away because they wanted to see the Blessed One’s incomparable, immeasurable, and unequalled miracle,

original: daṭṭhukāmā pakkantā?
analyzed: daṭṭhu kāmā pakkantā
translated: or did they go away because they wanted to see the Blessed One’s incomparable, immeasurable, and unequalled miracle?

original: Yadi, bhante nāgasena, bhagavatā bhaṇitaṁ—🔽‘vigatabhayasantāsā arahanto’ti, tena hi ‘nagare …pe…
analyzed: yadi bhante nāgasena bhagavatā bhaṇita  vigata bhaya santāsāḥ tena hi nagare
translated: If, revered Nāgasena, it was said by the Blessed One:

original: ānandan’ti yaṁ vacanaṁ taṁ micchā.
analyzed: ānandanti yam vacanam tam micchā
translated: ‘Arahats are free from fear and trembling,’ then it was wrong of them to go away from the city of Rājagaha, leaving the elder Ānanda behind.

original: Yadi nagare rājagahe dhanapālakaṁ hatthiṁ bhagavati opatantaṁ disvā pañca khīṇāsavasatāni
analyzed: yadi nagare rājagahe dhanapālakam hatthim bhagavati opatantam disvā pañca khīṇāsava satāni
translated: If, on seeing the elephant Dhanapālaka rush at the Blessed One in the city of Rājagaha, five hundred perfected beings

original: pariccajitvā jinavaraṁ pakkantāni disāvidisaṁ ekaṁ ṭhapetvā theraṁ ānandaṁ, tena
analyzed: pariccajitvā jina varam pakkantāni disāvidisam ekam ṭhapetvā theram ānanda tena
translated: abandoned him and went away in all directions, leaving only the Elder Ānanda behind,

original: hi ‘vigatabhayasantāsā arahanto’ti tampi vacanaṁ micchā.
analyzed: hi vigata bhaya santāsāḥ vacanam micchā
translated: then the statement ‘the perfected beings are free from fear and trembling’ is false.

original: Ayampi ubhato koṭiko pañho tavānuppatto, so tayā nibbāhitabbo”ti.
analyzed: ayam pi ubhatas koṭikaḥ pañho tava anuppatto saḥ tayā nibbāhitabbaḥ ti
translated: This double-pronged question has come up. You should resolve it.”

original: “Bhāsitampetaṁ, mahārāja, bhagavatā—
analyzed: mahā rāja bhagavatā
translated: “Great king, the Blessed One did say,

original: ‘vigatabhayasantāsā arahanto’ti, nagare rājagahe dhanapālakaṁ hatthiṁ bhagavati opatantaṁ
analyzed: vigata bhaya santāsāḥ nagare rājagahe dhanapālakam hatthim bhagavati opatanta
translated: ‘the perfected beings are free from fear and trembling.’ On seeing the elephant Dhanapālaka rush at the Blessed One in the city of Rājagaha,

original: disvā pañca khīṇāsavasatāni pariccajitvā jinavaraṁ pakkantāni disāvidisaṁ ekaṁ ṭhapetvā
analyzed: disvā pañca khīṇāsava satāni pariccajitvā jina varam pakkantāni disāvidisam ekam ṭhapetvā
translated: five hundred perfected beings abandoned him and went away in all directions, leaving only the Elder Ānanda behind.

original: theraṁ ānandaṁ, tañca pana na bhayā, nāpi bhagavantaṁ pātetukāmatāya.
analyzed: theram ānanda na na bhayā na api bhagavantam
translated: But that was not out of fear or a desire to avoid hurting the Blessed One.

original: Yena pana, mahārāja, hetunā arahanto bhāyeyyuṁ vā tāseyyuṁ vā, so hetu arahantānaṁ
analyzed: yena pana mahā rāja hetunā arahantaḥ bhāyeyyum vā tāseyyum vā saḥ hetu
translated: Great king, the reason why the perfected beings would be afraid or tremble,

original: samucchinno, tasmā vigatabhayasantāsā arahanto, bhāyati nu, mahārāja, mahāpathavī
analyzed: tasmai vigata bhaya santāsāḥ arahantaḥ bhāyati nu mahā rāja mahā pathavī
translated: Therefore, the arahats, being free from fear and trembling,

original: khaṇantepi bhindantepi dhārentepi samuddapabbatagirisikhare”ti?
analyzed: khaṇante api bhindante api dhārente api samudda pabbata giri sikharā iti
translated: does the great earth tremble when they dig, cut, carry away, or burn the mountains, cliffs, and mountain peaks?”

original: “Na hi, bhante”ti.
analyzed: na hi bhantā iti
translated: “No, venerable sir.”

original: “Kena kāraṇena, mahārājā”ti?
analyzed: kena kāraṇena mahā rājā ati
translated: “For what reason, great king?”

original: “Natthi, bhante, mahāpathaviyā so hetu, yena hetunā mahāpathavī bhāyeyya vā tāseyya vā”ti.
analyzed: natthi bhante mahā pathaviyā saḥ hetu yena hetunā mahā pathavī bhāyeyya vā tāseyya vā ati
translated: “There is no reason, venerable sir, why the great earth should tremble.”

original: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, natthi arahantānaṁ so hetu, yena hetunā arahanto bhāyeyyuṁ vā tāseyyuṁ vā.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja natthi arahantānam saḥ hetu yena hetunā arahantaḥ bhāyeyyum vā tāseyyum vā
translated: “Even so, great king, there is no reason why the arahats should tremble.

original: Bhāyati nu, mahārāja, girisikharaṁ chindante vā bhindante vā patante vā agginā dahante vā”ti?
analyzed: bhāyati nu mahā rāja giri sikharam chindante vā bhindante vā patante vā agginā dahante vā ati
translated: Does a mountain peak tremble when it is cut, split, or burnt by fire?”

original: “Na hi, bhante”ti.
analyzed: na hi bhantā iti
translated: “No, venerable sir.”

original: “Kena kāraṇena, mahārājā”ti?
analyzed: kena kāraṇena mahā rājā ati
translated: “For what reason, great king?”

original: “Natthi, bhante, girisikharassa so hetu, yena hetunā girisikharaṁ bhāyeyya vā tāseyya vā”ti.
analyzed: natthi bhante giri sikharassa saḥ hetu yena hetunā giri sikharam bhāyeyya vā tāseyya vā ati
translated: “There is no reason, venerable sir, why a mountain peak should tremble.”

original: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, natthi arahantānaṁ so hetu, yena hetunā arahanto bhāyeyyuṁ vā tāseyyuṁ vā.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja natthi arahantānam saḥ hetu yena hetunā arahantaḥ bhāyeyyum vā tāseyyum vā
translated: “Even so, sire, there is no reason why Arahants should be afraid or terrified.

original: Yadipi, mahārāja, lokadhātusatasahassesu ye keci sattanikāyapariyāpannā sabbepi te sattihatthā ekaṁ arahantaṁ upadhāvitvā tāseyyuṁ, na bhaveyya arahato cittassa kiñci aññathattaṁ.
analyzed: yadi pi mahā rāja lokadhātu sata sahassesu ye keci satta nikāya pariyāpannā sabbe api te satti hatthāḥ ekam arahantam upadhāvitvā na bhaveyya arahato cittassa kiñci
translated: If, sire, all the beings in a hundred thousand world systems were to rush upon an Arahant with drawn swords, there would be no change in his consciousness.

original: Kiṅkāraṇaṁ?
analyzed: kiṅkāraṇa
translated: Why is that?

original: Aṭṭhānamanavakāsatāya.🔽Api ca, mahārāja, tesaṁ khīṇāsavānaṁ evaṁ cetoparivitakko ahosi ‘ajja naravarapavare
analyzed: aṭṭhānam an avakāsa tāya  api ca mahā rāja tesam khīṇa āsavānam evam cetaḥ upari vitakkaḥ ahosi ajja nara vara pavare
translated: Because it is impossible and cannot happen.

original: jinavaravasabhe nagaravaramanuppaviṭṭhe vīthiyā dhanapālako hatthī āpatissati, asaṁsayamatidevadevaṁ🔽upaṭṭhāko na pariccajissati, yadi mayaṁ sabbepi bhagavantaṁ na pariccajissāma, ānandassa
analyzed: jinavara vasabhe nagara varam anuppaviṭṭhe vīthiyā dhanapālakaḥ hatthī āpatissati  upaṭṭhākaḥ na pariccajissati yadi mayam sabbe pi bhagavantam na pariccajissāma ānandassa
translated: Moreover, sire, this thought occurred to those who were free from the corruptions: ‘Today the Best of Men, the Best of Beings, the Supreme Man, the Lord of the Three Worlds, the Seer, the Buddha, the Supreme Trainer of those who are to be tamed, the Teacher of gods and men, the Blessed One, has entered the best of cities, the best of streets, and the best of houses.🔽The elephant Dhanapālaka will come along the street. Without doubt the most excellent of all gods will not abandon the most excellent of all men.

original: guṇo pākaṭo na bhavissati, na heva ca tathāgataṁ samupagamissati hatthināgo, handa
analyzed: guṇaḥ pākaṭaḥ na bhavissati na ha iva ca tathāgatam samupagamissati hatthi nāgaḥ handa
translated: If we all do not abandon the Blessed One, the virtue of Ānanda will not be evident.🔽And the elephant will not approach the Tathāgata. Let us therefore

original: mayaṁ apagacchāma, evamidaṁ mahato janakāyassa kilesabandhanamokkho bhavissati, ānandassa
analyzed: mayam apagacchāmaḥ evam idam mahataḥ jana kāyassa kilesa bandhana mokkhaḥ bhavissati ānandassa
translated: We will go away, and thus there will be deliverance for this great crowd from the bondage of defilements,

original: ca guṇo pākaṭo bhavissatī’ti.
analyzed: ca guṇaḥ pākaṭaḥ bhavissati iti
translated: and the virtue of Ānanda will be made manifest.’

original: Evaṁ te arahanto ānisaṁsaṁ disvā disāvidisaṁ pakkantā”ti.
analyzed: evam te arahantaḥ ānisasam disvā disāvidisam pakkantā ati
translated: Thus, after seeing the advantage, the Worthy Ones went away in all directions.”

original: “Suvibhatto, bhante nāgasena, pañho, evametaṁ natthi arahantānaṁ bhayaṁ vā santāso vā, ānisaṁsaṁ disvā arahanto pakkantā disāvidisan”ti.
analyzed: su vibhattaḥ bhante nāgasena pañhaḥ evam etam natthi arahantānam bhayam vā santāsaḥ vā ānisasam disvā arahantaḥ pakkantāḥ disā vidisanti
translated: “The question has been well analysed, revered Nāgasena, so it is, therefore there is no fear or terror for the Worthy Ones, after seeing the advantage the Worthy Ones went away in all directions.”

original: Arahantaabhāyanapañho navamo.
analyzed: arahantaabhāyanapañhaḥ navamo
translated: The ninth chapter.
